  • SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries lower, DXY higher, Crude lower
  • REAR-VIEW: European politics stabilises, NFP headline beat, wages steady
  • NEXT WEEK'S KEY EVENTS: Monday: UK Markit/CIPS Construction PMI // Tuesday: Japanese Services PMI, Caixin Services PMI, RBA Rate Decision, EZ Markit Services and Manufacturing PMI, US ISM Non-Manufacturing, UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI // Wednesday: Australian GDP // Thursday: EZ GDP (3rd Reading) // Friday: Japanese GDP, Canadian Jobs Data, G7 meeting in Canada

 

*TRADE WARS: German Economy Minister said that the EU may work with Mexico and Canada on trade, while Juncker confirmed the EU intention to lodge a WTO complaint against the US over tariffs. EU trade chief Malmstrom also noted negotiations are not possible at the moment with the US. Elsewhere, the WSJ reported Chinese officials are reluctant on long-term pacts with the US. It was also mentioned that long term pacts regarding energy and agriculture are being questioned. In a call with French President Macron, the White House reported US President Trump discussed the need to re-balance trade with Europe. We can expect the tone at the upcoming G7 meeting to be chilly towards the US, with the French finance minister saying the meeting will effectively be G6 versus 1. On NAFTA, Mexico’s Trade Negotiator Kalach says a skinny deal does not look possible at this stage, and similarly US NEC Director Kudlow noted NAFTA talks will play-out for a while. Later, US President Trump said he would be open to having separate trade deals with Canada and Mexico, though analysts doubt this is feasible.

*EUROPEAN POLITICS: The latest state of play saw Italy’s 5SM and League completing an accord on a coalition government and Italy's President Mattarella giving Conte the mandate to form his government. In terms of personnel, Di Maio and Salvini were named as deputy PM’s and the titles of Labour Minister and Interior Minister respectively with Tria Finance Minister and Milanesi as Foreign Minister. Markets met the announcement with some relief given the prospects of Savona heading up the finance ministry, which shook markets earlier in the week. Questions still remain surrounding the sustainability of such an alliance; Barclays states that “it will be difficult for a 5SM-League-led government to adopt in full its economic programme”. Ultimately, the possibility of snap elections remains plausible and if called, some have suggested that this could be seen as a proxy for an anti-EU referendum. As such, any fractions that emerge in the coalition next week could continue to send jitters around the market. Over in Spain, Socialist leader Sanchez was named PM after lawmakers vote Rajoy out of office with a 180 to 169 vote. This was very much expected after the socialist opposition party proposed the no confidence vote amid parties linked to Rajoy’s party corruption. New PM Sanchez does not wish to see new elections, and he wants the 2018 budget to remain in place, with the fiscal policy introduced by the previous government. He is also aiming to pass the 2019 budget and wishes to carry on the stability programme at least for this year. As a note of caution, Oxford Economics highlights that “Although Sánchez managed to obtain the backing from several parties to oust Rajoy, this was a sign of the widespread discontent with the Popular Party policies and corruption scandals, rather than an endorsement of the Socialists themselves as a real alternative”. New elections are already scheduled for 2020 but given the instability of the new government, a snap election appears likely. As for the market, though the situation will contribute to greater uncertainty, the overall impact should be limited as Spain is growing at a robust pace, it is not planning to boost government expenditure, for the moment, and in the country support for the EU is elevated, all factors that make it less of a risk for markets when compared to Italy.

*GEOPOLITICS: US President Trump says the meeting with Kim Jong Un is back on, it is to take place in Singapore on June 12th, also notes the North Korean’s do want to denuclearise and Trump does believe this is the case. North and South Korea have agreed to meet on June 12th for military talks. A senior lieutenant to North Korean leader Kim Jong Un is set to hand-deliver a letter to President Donald Trump in the White House on Friday, with the letter to express interests in meeting, according to WSJ.

*FED SPEAK: Fed's Kashkari (Non-voter, Dove) reiterated his view that wage growth is picking up at a slow pace, though he expected it to be stronger given the low rate of unemployment. He also added that wage growth is still lower than expected and slack remains in labour market.

Fed’s Williams (Voter, Central) says Fed should continue with gradual hikes over the upcoming two years, expects US rates to be neutral after three more hikes and says Fed should not necessarily pause once it reaches neutral if economy remains firm rates could rise above neutral for a period of time.

*DATA: Official Non-Farm Payrolls posted a 223K gain, beating expectations at 188K, the Unemployment Rate came in at 3.8% the lowest in 18 years, whilst Average Hourly Earnings was unchanged at 2.7%. The overall strength of the labour report increases the likes of a rate hike in June, analysts say. Looking at the payroll components, 31,000 was the increase in retail, 25,000 in construction and 23,000 in professional and technical services. The household survey employment measure was up by 293K in June which together with the 12K increase in the labour force explains the fall in unemployment to 3.8%, though this was also attributed to a fall in the participation rate (62.7%). Capital Economics said that all sectors are performing well, adding to the already strong economic outlook. In this scenario, the Fed is still expected to hike rates at least three times this year, with political uncertainty fading in Italy and trade war impacts to be limited given exports only make up 12% of GDP, the consultancy said. Elsewhere, the ISM Manufacturing came in at 58.7, a touch above the consensus of 58.2. The gains were attributed to a rebound in new orders, production and employment which added to the weakness seen in March and April. On the flip side, inventories and export orders fell. The softness seen in the previous months was said to be led by bad weather and trade war fear. Construction Spending MM was at 1.8% in April, a big beat on the 0.8% consensus, mostly due to gains in the private residential sector, specifically multi-family units and home improvements. Spending in the public sector fell however. Though the headline rebounded to early Q1 levels, data in the incoming months is necessary to understand the direction of Q2.

*EQUITIES: SPX +1.07% at 2734 , NDX +1.67% at 7084, DJI +0.89% at 24633.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals +0.70%, Cons Non-Cyclicals:-0.03%, Energy: +0.50%, Financials: +1.1%%, Health Care: +1.2%, Industrials: +1.2%, Materials: +1.5%, Telecom: +0.2%, Tech: +2.00%, Utilities: -1.5%

US Equity futures benefitted from a risk-on tone on Friday, as political tensions eased in Europe. The constructive risk environment saw the S&P 500 Emini grinding higher through the course of the session, despite a slight dip following the US jobs report; however, downticks were fleeting and the futures resumed ricking higher through the course of the session, breaking the key 2730 level but finding resistance just shy of 2740 where selling was observed.

Sectors: Utilities expressed its defensive nature again due to the risk-on tone, and it closed heavily in the red where it was totting-up losses around 2%; the outperformers were led by tech, carrying on its recent gains. Utility names and energy names seemed to be weighing on Friday, again due to the defensive nature, while lower oil prices were also cited.

Thursday after market Costco (COST) beat on the bottom line but missed on its top line, resulting in the stock closing red; earnings from Lululemon (LULU) stood out as its report was seen as one of the best for its sector, and the stock saw intraday highs just shy of 18% after its EPS & revenue beat, as well as raising its FY18 EPS outlook.

*CRUDE: WTI futures (July) settle $1.23 lower at $65.81/bbl; Brent futures (August) settle $0.77 lower at $76.79. The arb between WTI and Brent continues to widen, on Friday rising to over $11; WTI once again underperformed Brent; the prevailing wisdom is that infrastructure bottlenecks and continued rising crude production rates in the US is dragging on WTI (Baker Hughes reported oil rigs rose for the second straight week to 861 from 859), while Brent is supported by OPEC+ jawboning, despite the potential for a relaxation of supply curbs that the cartel and its partners are expected to announce in June; additionally, and of more note on Friday, was news that supply of the five grades that underpin Brent will slip in July by 30k BPD to 910k BPD. It was also reported today that the Saudis are planning to raise their crude OSP to Asia for the second straight month. Later, it was reported that an OPEC+ ministerial monitoring committee will hold an unofficial meeting on Saturday in Kuwait, though Russia and Venezuela will not attend.

*FIXED INCOME: US 10yr T-Notes futures (Sep 2018) settled 19 ticks lower at 119-27. The Treasury complex was under pressure for most of Friday, along with decent volume, as political tensions in Europe eased, a decent NFP report, and news that the summit with North Korea is back on. However, although yields were higher across the curve by between 6-8bps, major curves continued to narrow, with 2s30s over 2bps narrower, and 5s30s flatter by around the same margin; 2s5s was relatively unchanged.

*FX WEEKLY REVIEW:  USD: Volatile trade amidst various direct and indirect drivers, with Italian politics the dominant theme in the run up to latest US jobs data and the return of trade wars after the US imposed sanctions vs the EU, Canada and Mexico, sparking a mixture of verbal and physical counter-actions. The index is actually closing out Friday’s session close to where it was at the start of the week and just over 94.000, having registered a fresh ytd peak on Tuesday (95.030) when events in Rome were really reverberating across global financial markets and reaching contagious if not systemic risk averse proportions. However, Italy’s populist parties eventually agreed on a coalition Government compromise that keeps Savona in the cabinet, but out of the prominent Finance Minister post that President Mattarella blocked, to resolve the situation and avoid snap elections. Back to the BLS report, all metrics were better than forecast aside from y/y average earnings, and this along with a tweet from the US President effectively pre-empting upbeat news nullified or dampened the subsequent reaction.

EUR: The single currency has almost moved in lock-step with Italian assets on unfolding developments, and has recovered from a new 2018 low vs the Greenback (just above 1.1500) towards 1.1700 where very large option expiries have curtailed a firmer rebound (at the figure and extending to 1.1750). Note, some late Friday Eur selling was seen where a brief re-test of the 1.1600 handle was used as a support.

CAD: Very choppy moves in the Loonie, with the BoC’s hawkish hold on Wednesday boosting the Cad to near 1.2800 highs vs its US counterpart, but then a sharp fall from grace and slump to 1.3000 after a considerable miss on the annualised Canadian GDP miss and reciprocal steel/aluminium tariffs against the US, plus further delay in NAFTA negotiations.

GBP: Relatively resilient vs the Usd after its return from Monday’s late May UK holiday, with Cable returning to 1.3300+ levels from a near 1.3200 low with the aid of a stronger than expected manufacturing PMI and reports that a solution to the contentious Irish border issue may be forthcoming via a dual UK-EU arrangement whereby the island assumes both sets of regulations.

JPY, CHF: Mixed fortunes for the traditional safe-havens in line with changes in overall risk sentiment, but both rangebound overall between 108.10-109.75 and 0.9820-0.9985 respectively vs the Dollar.

AUD, NZD: As above, the antipodean dollars have been hostage to broader risk-off/on fluctuations, but also some disappointing data and very big option-related flows. The Aud has found 0.7600 formidable to breach as a result and Kiwi 0.7000, while the cross pivots 1.0800.

SEK, NOK: Solid weeks on balance for the Scandi crowns vs the Eur on a combination of upbeat data/surveys and more Central Bank rhetoric maintaining pre-year end tightening prospects, while the Sek received and additional lift from the SNDO hedging for a stronger currency.

TRY, MXN: More whippy moves, with the Lira deriving some support from CBRT clarity on monetary policy, but still plagued by Turkey’s economic and fiscal problems and spec that ratings agencies may cut the sovereign, while the Peso has suffered alongside the Cad on US trade and NAFTA dynamics. Usd/Try almost up to 4.6500 and Usd/Mxn hit 20.000 at various stages.

*WEEK AHEAD: Next week's key events: Monday: UK Markit/CIPS Construction PMI // Tuesday: Japanese Services PMI, Caixin Services PMI, RBA Rate Decision, EZ Markit Services and Manufacturing PMI, US ISM Non-Manufacturing, UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI // Wednesday: Australian GDP // Thursday: EZ GDP (3rd Reading) // Friday: Japanese GDP, Canadian Jobs Data, G7 meeting in Canada. subject: Fixed and FX latest: knee-jerk moves post-NFP, so far
content: An almost blanket beat vs consensus, bar y/y average earnings, but perhaps the Trump tweet ahead of the official BLS report stole the show and market reactions to the actual numbers have been relatively muted as a result. Whatever the reason/rationale, Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries have bounced from new intraday lows of 160.99, 122.85 and 119-19, while Dollar bulls have not received that much for their buck with only Usd/Jpy holding the bulk of its gains and remaining above 109.50 vs Eur/Usd off circa 1.1650 and Cable back above 1.3300.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 1st June 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Italian assets seeing significant positivity as government edges closer
  • Spanish PM Rajoy ousted as Socialist Sanchez takes power
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US NFP, ISM mfg, Baker Hughes and Fed’s Kashkari

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks traded cautiously after trade war concerns resurfaced following the US announcement to impose steel and aluminium tariffs on EU, Canada and Mexico, which in turn triggered threats of retaliation against the US. In addition, a slight miss on Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI data and looming US NFP jobs data have added to the tentative tone. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was led lower by financials with ANZ Bank pressured on cartel allegation charges related to a share sale in 2015 and as the energy sector also suffered from weakness in crude prices, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) shrugged off its opening losses on favourable currency moves. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were indecisive and swung between gains and losses as participants digested a range of factors including weaker than expected Caixin Manufacturing PMI data and a firm net liquidity injection of CNY 410bln for the week, as well as the debut of China A-shares in the MSCI Emerging Market benchmark index. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower after the BoJ reduced purchases of 5yr-10yr maturities in its Rinban announcement which saw a breakdown of near-term support at 150.94, while price action was also consistent with a recovery in Tokyo stocks and US yields.

Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (May) 51.1 vs. Exp. 51.2 (Prev. 51.1). (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 40bln via 7-day reverse repos, CNY 10bln via 14-day reverse repos and CNY 30bln via 28-day reverse repos, for a net weekly injection of CNY 410bln vs. last week's CNY 30bln net drain. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4078 (Prev. 6.4144)

EU/UK/US

UK Brexit Secretary Davis is reported to be drawing up a new plan that would give Northern Ireland joint EU/UK status as well as border buffer zone. The province would operate a double hatted regime of European and British regulations simultaneously, so it can trade freely with both. Branded a ‘special economic zone’, it will be for local traders such as dairy farmers – who make up 90 per cent of the cross-border traffic – and share the same trade rules as south of the border. This idea has confirmed to be discussed by a senior British official. (The Sun/Newswires)

Spain's Socialist leader Sanchez becomes PM after lawmakers vote Rajoy out of office. The vote was 180 to 169 with the passing of the vote very much expected. Prior to this Rajoy accepted his defeat and said that Sanchez is set to be the new PM. (Newswires)

UK Markit/CIPS Manufacturing PMI (May) 54.4 vs. Exp. 53.5 (Prev. 53.9)

EU Markit Manufacturing Final PMI (May) 55.5 vs. Exp. 55.5 (Prev. 55.5)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed's Bullard (Non-Voter, Dove) reiterates already at a neutral rate, adds appropriate for Fed to hedge views on rate hikes and that inflation would have surprise to the upside for rate hikes. (Newswires)

TRADE

US metal tariff exemptions for EU, Canada and Mexico expired overnight which sees US’ closest allies to be subject to 25% tariffs on steel and 10% on aluminium heading into the US. Elsewhere, there were also comments from President Trump that the US will agree to a fair NAFTA deal or no deal at all. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

North Korean leader Kim said their will for denuclearization of the peninsula is unchanged, consistent and fixed, while he hopes that North Korea and US ties will be solved step by step and added North Korea has agreed to a summit with Russia. North and South Korea have agreed to meet on June 14th for military talks. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities bounced back from yesterday’s losses (Eurostoxx 50 +1.1%) with all the major bourses firmly in the green.

Italy’s FTSE MIB (+2.8%) is outperforming its counterparts amid a coalition deal revival by the Italian populist parties.

As a result, Italian banks are leading the gains with the Italian Bank Index higher by over 5%.

Across the continent, Spain’s IBEX (+1.7%) is showing a solid performance while the country’s PM Rajoy accepts his defeat and says opposition Sanchez is set to be the PM.

Elsewhere, Deutsche Bank (+3.0%) tries to nurture yesterday’s wounds (shares dropped to record lows after US subsidiaries were added to a federal problem bank list) after ECB sources reassures investors that the bank now has a tighter management team, good liquidity and capital.

Finally, Dialog Semiconductors (-14.9%) is the most noticeable mover in the Stoxx 600 after a revenue warning amid tech giant Apple building their own chips.

FX

DXY

The index is straddling 94.000 ahead of today’s US jobs data amidst relatively narrow bands for most Dollar/G10 pairings, bar Usd/JPY that has broken above 109.00 and into a firmer trading range amidst a broad improvement in risk sentiment on Italian political grounds over heightened global trade tensions. However, Jpy bears and Greenback bulls may encounter more offers at 109.50 and some technical resistance ahead of the 30 DMA around 109.56.

CAD

A partial recovery for the Loonie after Thursday’s post-Canadian GDP data dive, with Usd/Cad retreating from circa 1.3000 to sub-1.2950, and perhaps acknowledging retaliatory action against US steel and aluminium tariffs rather than dwelling on NAFTA deal prospects that look more remote.

AUD

Another relative underperformer despite exemptions from the aforementioned US import taxes, with 0.7600 still proving to be a formidable chart hurdle to overcome convincingly and a softer Caixin Chinese manufacturing PMI also undermining the Aud.

EUR/GBP

Both largely unchanged vs the Usd, with the single currency consolidating its comeback from 2018 lows above 1.1600, but still unable to breach 1.1700 sustainably and facing hefty option expiries at the strike (4.6 bn). Similarly, Cable appears capped around 1.3300, and indeed the big figure has held in wake of a decent UK manufacturing beat.

NZD/CHF

Idling well within recent trading parameters vs the US Dollar, with the Kiwi pivoting 0.7000 and Franc towards the middle of a 0.9840-90 range.

TRY

The Lira is lagging other EMs and not deriving any support from latest CBRT operations, as Usd/Try rebounds back above 4.6000 in wake of a further/faster contraction in Turkey’s manufacturing PMI.

FIXED INCOME

Italian bonds have now reversed all and more of Tuesday’s colossal losses as the 10 year BTP breaches resistance around 129.00 and races towards 130.00 amidst stops and technical buying targeting the next bullish chart objective around 130.20. 129.82 is the latest pinnacle reached vs the 120.10 low when Rome was burning amidst the almost unprecedented Presidential rejection of proposed Economy Minister Savona. However, the inverse/negative loop to core bonds appears to have broken down somewhat as Bunds hold above worst levels and Gilts retain grasp of 123.00 even though the UK manufacturing PMI exceeded median forecasts (albeit thanks to inventories in the main). Elsewhere, US Treasuries are just off marginal new overnight session lows awaiting some independent impetus and a distraction from the Italian politics/trade war drivers via NFP.

COMMODITIES

Oil is up on the day heading into the weekend with both WTI and Brent up modestly on the day after touching lows in late US trade. This comes after bearish signals in products within the DoE data discounted a wider than expected crude draw. A broader risk averse tone spurred on by trade concerns is dampening prices slightly, however.

Gold is lacklustre with the yellow metal essentially flat on the day with traders holding fire ahead of US jobs data. Steel has extended its climb to hit multi-month highs, with aluminium also rising slightly on the day amid the imposition and retaliation of tariffs, as well as continually declining steel stockpiles.

Bunds: on the back foot again, as BTPs resume recovery rally
content: An early attempt to rebound off a weaker Eurex open was thwarted by the latest firm bounce in BTPs as investors respond positively (for now) to news that Italy’s populist parties have finally settled on a coalition Government, thereby averting the added complication of a snap election. The 10 year German debt future kicked off Friday’s session at 161.67, then climbed to 161.83 fleetingly before reversing to a 161.23 low, while the Italian benchmark gapped up 153 ticks initially, but has extended gains to 241 ticks at 128.62 since. Ahead, Eurozone manufacturing PMIs look like mere fillers ahead of NFP, but politics will continue to be a focus as attention switches to Spain and the no confidence vote in Madrid that seems certain to seal the end for PM Rajoy.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

1st June 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded cautiously after trade war concerns resurfaced following the US announcement to impose steel and aluminium tariffs on EU, Canada and Mexico, which in turn triggered threats of retaliation against the US. In addition, a slight miss on Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI data and looming US NFP jobs data have added to the tentative tone. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was led lower by financials with ANZ Bank pressured on cartel allegation charges related to a share sale in 2015 and as the energy sector also suffered from weakness in crude prices, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) shrugged off its opening losses on favourable currency moves. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were indecisive and swung between gains and losses as participants digested a range of factors including weaker than expected Caixin Manufacturing PMI data and a firm net liquidity injection of CNY 410bln for the week, as well as the debut of China A-shares in the MSCI Emerging Market benchmark index. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower after the BoJ reduced purchases of 5yr-10yr maturities in its Rinban announcement which saw a breakdown of near-term support at 150.94, while price action was also consistent with a recovery in Tokyo stocks and US yields.

US equity futures traded higher overnight, following on from yesterday’s rebound where it consolidated around the recently watched 2730 level. There was downside as European traders got to their desks, and the Emini S&P futures started to slide as markets awaited US Commerce Secretary Ross announcements on tariffs. subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 1st June 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Italy’s 5SM and League completed an accord on a coalition government with Conte now given the mandate to form a 5 Star/League coalition government
  • Asian stocks traded cautiously after trade war concerns resurfaced following the US announcement to impose steel and aluminium tariffs on EU, Canada and Mexico
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK and Eurozone mfg PMIs, US NFP, ISM mfg, Baker Hughes and Fed’s Kashkari

 

TRADE

US metal tariff exemptions for EU, Canada and Mexico expired overnight which sees US’ closest allies to be subject to 25% tariffs on steel and 10% on aluminium heading into the US. Elsewhere, there were also comments from President Trump that the US will agree to a fair NAFTA deal or no deal at all. (Newswires)

Mexico’s Economy Minister Guajardo said it would be difficult to reach a NAFTA deal before the Mexican election following the US tariff decision but added that talks are still continuing. Guajardo also commented he does not expect a trade war after US tariffs on steel and aluminium and that tariffs affect USD 4bln of trade between Mexico and the US. (Newswires)

Canada PM Trudeau said they will establish proportional compensatory measures to US tariffs and stated he was told a five-year sunset clause was a pre-condition for a meeting with President Trump to finalise NAFTA, which he said Canada could not accept. (Newswires)

UK Trade Minister Fox said the UK is not ruling out counter measures after the US imposed steel and aluminium tariffs. (Newswires)
 

ASIA

Asian stocks traded cautiously after trade war concerns resurfaced following the US announcement to impose steel and aluminium tariffs on EU, Canada and Mexico, which in turn triggered threats of retaliation against the US. In addition, a slight miss on Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI data and looming US NFP jobs data have added to the tentative tone. ASX 200 (-0.4%) was led lower by financials with ANZ Bank pressured on cartel allegation charges related to a share sale in 2015 and as the energy sector also suffered from weakness in crude prices, while Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) shrugged off its opening losses on favourable currency moves. Hang Seng (-0.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.5%) were indecisive and swung between gains and losses as participants digested a range of factors including weaker than expected Caixin Manufacturing PMI data and a firm net liquidity injection of CNY 410bln for the week, as well as the debut of China A-shares in the MSCI Emerging Market benchmark index. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower after the BoJ reduced purchases of 5yr-10yr maturities in its Rinban announcement which saw a breakdown of near-term support at 150.94, while price action was also consistent with a recovery in Tokyo stocks and US yields.

Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI (May) 51.1 vs. Exp. 51.2 (Prev. 51.1). (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 40bln via 7-day reverse repos, CNY 10bln via 14-day reverse repos and CNY 30bln via 28-day reverse repos, for a net weekly injection of CNY 410bln vs. last week's CNY 30bln net drain. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4078 (Prev. 6.4144)


UK/EU

BoE’s Governor Carney said UK real wages have not risen in a decade and stated that focus on trade in goods is not the right one, when asked about the fresh US tariffs. (Newswires)
 

UK Brexit Secretary Davis is reported to be drawing up a new plan that would give Northern Ireland joint EU/UK status as well as border buffer zone. The province would operate a double hatted regime of European and British regulations simultaneously, so it can trade freely with both. Branded a ‘special economic zone’, it will be for local traders such as dairy farmers – who make up 90 per cent of the cross-border traffic – and share the same trade rules as south of the border. (The Sun)

A group of Labour supporters and trade unions are to launch a major campaign to shift the party’s position on Brexit. The organisers are to argue that a programme of economic reform would be hampered by a damaging exit from the EU, which may threaten jobs and investments. (The Guardian)
 

Italy’s 5SM and League completed an accord on a coalition government and Italy's President Mattarella later gave Conte the mandate to form a 5 Star/League coalition government, which Conte accepted and is to be sworn in on Friday. Italy's Conte said M5S leader Di Maio to be Labour and Industry Minister and Deputy PM, League leader Salvini is to be Interior Minister and Deputy PM, while Tria was nominated as Finance Minister and Milanesi as Foreign Minister. (Newswires)


FX

The USD saw marginal gains overnight in which the DXY reclaimed the 94.00 level amid higher yields overnight. This slightly pressured its major counterparts with GBP/USD extending on losses after initial recovery attempts were hampered by resistance at 1.3300, while losses in EUR/USD were limited following the progress in Italian politics with Conte set to be sworn in as PM under a M5S-League coalition government on Friday. Elsewhere, JPY was weaker across the board with USD/JPY reclaiming the 109.00 handle, while MXN and CAD were subdued following the US tariff announcement and with the latter also reeling from the recent Canadian GDP miss.


COMMODITIES

Commodities were uneventful overnight with WTI crude futures below the USD 67.00/bbl amid the risk averse tone across global markets and a slightly firmer greenback, while yesterday’s wider than expected DoE crude draw failed to provide any sustained support. Gold prices were also subdued with the precious metal stuck near the prior day’s lows as participants remained tentative ahead of the upcoming US jobs data, and copper also lacked impetus amid the indecision seen in Chinese markets.

US extended sanctions deadline on 3 firms linked to Deripaska including Rusal (486 HK) and EN+. (Newswires)


GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump said there is ‘a very good chance’ a denuclearization deal with North Korea will require more than one meeting and that it will cover missiles. Elsewhere, US Secretary of State Pompeo said he is confident things are proceeding in the correct direction and that they have made real progress in the past few days, while he believes North Korea is contemplating a fundamentally different track from the past. (Newswires)

North Korean leader Kim said their will for denuclearization of the peninsula is unchanged, consistent and fixed, while he hopes that North Korea and US ties will be solved step by step and added North Korea has agreed to a summit with Russia. (Newswires)
 

US

Treasury futures were mixed on Thursday, though the general bias was towards lower yields, supported by trade war fears after the US slapped tariffs on EU, Canada and Mexico. The complex saw a moderate sell off a bit later in the session after Italy agreed on a government deal but then paired back those losses as focus moved on Spain. Volume was thin in the front contract as open interest shifted into September contract. Most of the price action was concentrated in the belly and long ends of the curve, where yields were lower by c.1bps; 2s10s and 2s30s where narrower by c.3bps with the former at the flattest level in nearly 11 years. US 10yr T-Notes futures (Sep 2018) settled 45 ticks higher at 120-14.

Fed's Brainard (Voter, Dove) said gradual rate hikes appropriate but stated the Fed is alert to emerging market risks and ready to adjust policy as needed. Brainard also commented that above trend growth and stimulus calls for gradual hikes, while she added that global financial market stress and possible channels to US are important consideration for monetary policy. (Newswires)

Fed’s Mester (Voter, Hawk) suggested rates should be raised gradually and noted wages are rising which will be reflected in data soon. Furthermore, Mester does not see inflation spiking higher and noted Italy has not changed the view of economic fundamentals in the US. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (Non-Voter, Dove) reiterated that they are already at a neutral rate and that it is appropriate for Fed to hedge views on rate hikes, while he added that inflation would have to surprise to the upside for rate hikes. (Newswires)

content:
Asia stocks trade choppy with the region cautious after trade war concerns resurfaced following the US announcement to impose steel and aluminium tariffs on EU, Canada and Mexico, which in turn triggered threats of retaliation against the US. In addition, a slight miss on Chinese Caixin Manufacturing PMI data and looming US NFP jobs data have added to the tentative tone. ASX 200 (-0.4%) is led lower by financials with ANZ Bank pressured on cartel allegation charges related to a share sale in 2015 and with energy also suffering from weakness in crude prices, while Nikkei 225 (+0.4%) shrugged off its opening losses on favourable currency moves. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.3%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) are indecisive with participants digesting a range of factors including weaker than expected Caixin Manufacturing PMI data and a firm net liquidity injection of CNY 410bln for the week, as well as the debut of China A-shares in the MSCI Emerging Market benchmark index.  

In FX markets, the USD is relatively flat ahead of the key US jobs data today with the DXY just about reclaiming the 94.00 level amid higher yields overnight. As such, the greenback is mixed against its major counterparts with EUR/USD holding firm following the progress in Italian politics with Conte set to be sworn in as PM under a M5S-League coalition government on Friday, while GBP/USD languishes after recovery attempts were hampered by resistance at 1.3300. Elsewhere, JPY is weaker across the board with USD/JPY reclaiming the 109.00 handle, antipodeans are mixed and are dictated by further losses in AUD/NZD, while MXN and CAD are subdued following the US tariff announcement and with the latter also reeling from the recent Canadian GDP miss.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower after the BoJ reduced purchases of 5yr-10yr maturities in its Rinban announcement which saw a breakdown of near-term support at 150.94, while price action was also consistent with a recovery in Tokyo stocks and US yields.
